questions.text: The apoprotein responsible for transport of the lipoprotein from the plasma into the liver is?
questions.solution:
The apoprotein that causes remnant uptake is apo-E which transports the lipoprotein from the plasma to the liver. Apo-E is stored in HDL and transferred into the lipoproteins when required. Apo-E is present on all lipoproteins except LDL

Functions of other lipoproteins are given below:

Apo-C 2: Lipoprotein lipase cofactor that catalyzes cleavage

Apo-A1: apoprotein that activates LCAT. LCAT causes maturation of HDL lipoprotein

Apo-B: it is a marker of origin of the lipoprotein

Apo-B100 is a marker of the lipoprotein originating from the liver. Eg. VLDL, IDL, LDL

Apo-B48 is a marker of intestinal origin. Eg. Chylomicron, Chylomicron remnant

questions.text: Active form of Vit. D is?
questions.solution:
• The active form of Vit. D is 1, 25 (OH)2 Vit. D is also called Calcitriol.
  • Cholecalciferol, either synthesized in the skin or from food, undergoes two hydroxylations to yield the active metabolite, 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D or calcitriol.
  • Ergocalciferol from fortified foods undergoes similar hydroxylation to yield ercalcitriol.
  • In the liver, cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form the 25-hydroxy derivative, calcidiol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D-binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin.
  • In the kidney, calcidiol undergoes either 1-hydroxylation to yield the active metabolite 1,25-dihydroxy vitamin D (calcitriol), or 24-hydroxylation to yield a probably inactive metabolite, 24,25-dihydroxy vitamin D (24-hydroxy calcidiol).
  • Some tissues, other than those that are involved in calcium homeostasis, take up calcidiol from the circulation and synthesize calcitriol that acts within that cell.

questions.text: The primary ketone body is?
questions.solution:
• The primary ketone body is Acetoacetate formed by two Acetyl CoA molecules within mitochondria of hepatocytes only.
  • Beta hydroxybutyrate is produced from acetoacetate which is the major ketone body in ketoacidosis, about 3 times that of acetoacetate in concentration.
  • Acetone is also a ketone body produced from Acetoacetate non-enzymatically by an irreversible reaction.

questions.text: During Steatorrhea, absorption of which of the following vitamin is impaired?
questions.solution:
• Defective digestion or absorption leads to excretion of fat in stool which is known as Steatorrhea (stear means fat).
  • Defective digestion due to obstruction to bile secretion (Bile duct stone, tumor) or Pancreatic disorders like pancreatitis, Carcinoma of pancrease.
  • Defective absorption occurs in diseases of small intestine like Celiac disease, Crohn's disease or surgical removal of intestine
  • When there is a defect in digestion, undigested fat is excreted in stool, whereas when there is a defect in absorption, then digested fat is excreted in stool.
  • All lipid-soluble vitamins (Vitamin A (Retinol, Retinal, Retinoic acid), Vitamin D, Vitamin E & Vitamin K are hydrophobic compounds that can be absorbed efficiently only when there is normal fat absorption. During defective fat absorption, absorption of fat-soluble vitamins is impaired.

Option A, B, C: Vitamin B12, Folic acid, Thiamine are water soluble their absorption is not impaired in steatorrhea.

Option D: Retinol is vitamin A compound, which absorption is impaired in steatorrhea.

questions.text: Worms shown below in picture were recovered from stool specimens of several dogs that work in sheep ranches. Examination reveals tapeworms that measure <10 mm (shown in the image). Which medically important disease is linked to this worm?
questions.solution:
Echinococcosis (also known as hydatid disease) is caused by the tapeworm Echinococcus species, particularly Echinococcus granulosus (the most common species responsible for hydatid cysts in humans).

  • This disease involves dogs as the definitive host, which harbor the adult tapeworm in their intestines.
  • The life cycle of Echinococcus granulosus involves two hosts: the definitive host (typically dogs or other carnivores) and the intermediate host (usually herbivores like sheep or cattle, or humans as accidental hosts).
  • In the definitive host, adult tapeworms live in the intestines and release eggs in the feces. These eggs contaminate the environment, and when ingested by an intermediate host, the eggs hatch into larvae that penetrate the intestinal wall and travel to organs (most commonly the liver and lungs).
  • There, they form cysts containing protoscolices (larval tapeworms). Carnivores become infected by eating the organs of infected intermediate hosts, completing the cycle. Humans can accidentally ingest eggs from contaminated food, water, or soil, leading to the formation of hydatid cysts in their organs.

Incorrect options:

Option B) Schistosomiasis: Schistosomiasis is caused by flukes, not tapeworms, and the worms in question are much larger and not observed in dogs with sheep-related activity.

Option C): Diphyllobothriasis is caused by the tapeworm Diphyllobothrium latum and is typically associated with the consumption of raw fish. This tapeworm can grow to lengths of several meters, much longer than the small (10 mm) tapeworms described in this case.

Option D): Taeniasis is caused by the tapeworms of the genus Taenia, particularly Taenia solium (pork tapeworm) or Taenia saginata (beef tapeworm). These tapeworms can grow to several meters in length, much larger than the tapeworms described here (less than 10 mm).

  • Taenia species typically infect humans who ingest undercooked pork or beef containing cysticerci (larval tapeworms). While dogs can sometimes harbor Taenia larvae, the tapeworms associated with taeniasis are generally much larger than 10 mm.

questions.text: Identify the image
questions.solution:
Image A shows KOH mount-Characteristic appearance showing dichotomous branching/Acute angle branching (45 degree angle)

Image B shows characteristic appearance with conidiophores having vesicles with chain of conidia borne on elongated cells called sterigmata.

Aspergillus is a mould (part of the Ascomycota), and one of the key diagnostic features of some Aspergillus species (e.g., Aspergillus fumigatus) is their dichotomous branching of the conidiophores (the structures that produce conidia, or spores).

  • Conidiophores in Aspergillus species often branch in a dichotomous manner, meaning that the branches fork evenly, usually at an angle of 45° or so, forming a "Y"-shaped structure. This is a distinctive feature in the identification of Aspergillus under the microscope when preparing a KOH mount.
  • Aspergillus conidiophores can also have chains of conidia at the tips of these dichotomously branching structures. This dichotomous branching is a key characteristic used in the identification of Aspergillus species.

Incorrect options:

Option (A):

  • Zygomycetes are a class of fungi that include organisms like Rhizopus and Mucor. They typically have non-septate, coenocytic hyphae (meaning the hyphae do not have cross walls).
  • In Zygomycetes, branching is not typically dichotomous (forking at an angle); rather, they often show random, irregular branching. Zygomycetes are more commonly recognized by their sporangia and sporangiophores, not by dichotomous branching.

Option (C):

  • Candida is a genus of yeasts (like Candida albicans), and in its typical form, it does not exhibit dichotomous branching. Candida species can form pseudohyphae, which are chains of yeast cells that elongate but do not branch dichotomously.
  • Sheesh kebab effect
  • Germ tube test - keep candida with growth factor - Reynold Braude Phenomenon.
  • Candida will form chlamydospores formed on Corn meal agar.

Option (D):

  • Cryptococcus is another yeast (e.g., Cryptococcus neoformans), and it is distinguished by its large, polysaccharide capsule.
  • Cryptococcus generally does not form hyphae, and it grows as budding yeast cells. If it does form pseudohyphae, the branching is not dichotomous; pseudohyphae are typically elongated buds that remain attached in a chain-like fashion.

questions.text: Galactomannan antigen test in patient's sera or urine (by ELISA) is used for which of the following organism?
questions.solution:
• Aspergillus: The galactomannan antigen test (often performed using an enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay, or ELISA) is highly specific for Aspergillus
  • The presence of galactomannan in the serum or urine indicates an invasive aspergillosis infection, which is a significant concern, especially in immunocompromised patients (e.g., those with leukemia, stem cell transplants, or those on immunosuppressive therapy).

Incorrect options:

Option (A):

  • Candida: Candida infections are usually diagnosed using culture, microscopy, or specific tests such as beta-D-glucan assays, but galactomannan is not used for Candida.
  • 1,3 beta D glucan assay:
    • invasive candidiasis
    • invasive aspergillosis
    • pneumocystis jirovichi.

Option (B):

  • Mucor: Mucor and other Zygomycetes (e.g., Rhizopus) do not contain galactomannan. Therefore, the galactomannan antigen test is not used for diagnosing Mucor infections.

Option (D):

  • Cryptococcus: The diagnosis of Cryptococcus (particularly cryptococcal meningitis) is typically done using cryptococcal antigen testing (CrAg) or India ink staining, not the galactomannan antigen test.

questions.text: Which of the following molecule is the link between Gluconeogenesis, glycogenesis and glycogenolysis.
questions.solution: • Glucose 6-phosphate is an important compound at the junction of several metabolic pathways: glycolysis, gluconeogenesis, the pentose phosphate pathway glycogenesis, and glycogenolysis.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy has a problem of increased thirst and an increased diet along with cataract in his eyes. On laboratory examination, his blood sugar level is 205 mg/dl in fasting condition. Which of the following sugar alcohol is responsible for the development of cataract?
questions.solution:
• Both fructose and sorbitol are found in the lens of the eye in increased concentrations in diabetes mellitus and may be involved in the pathogenesis of diabetic cataract.
  • The sorbitol (polyol) pathway (not found in the liver) is responsible for fructose formation from glucose and increases in activity as the glucose concentration rises in those tissues that are not insulin-sensitive i.e. the lens, peripheral nerves, and renal glomeruli.
  • Glucose is reduced to sorbitol by aldose reductase, followed by oxidation of sorbitol to fructose in the presence of NAD+ and sorbitol dehydrogenase (polyol dehydrogenase). Sorbitol does not diffuse through cell membranes, but accumulates, causing osmotic damage. Simultaneously, myoinositol levels fall.
  • In experimental animals, sorbitol accumulation and myoinositol depletion, as well as diabetic cataract, can be prevented by aldose reductase inhibitors. One inhibitor has been licensed in Japan for the treatment of diabetic neuropathy, although there is little or no evidence that inhibitors are effective in preventing cataract or slowing the progression of diabetic neuropathy in human beings.

questions.text: Glycosphingolipid is made up of except
questions.solution:
Glycosphingolipids contain sphingosine, not glycerol.

Phospholipids

Lipids containing phosphoric acid and nitrogenous base in addition to glycerol and fatty acid. Fatty Acid + Alcohol (Glycerol/Sphingosine) + Phosphate + Nitrogenous base

Glycerophospholipids

The alcohol in this group is Glycerol, e.g. Lecithin, Cephalin.

Sphingophospholipids

The alcohol in this group is Sphingosine, e.g. Sphingomyelin.

Glycolipids or Glycosphingolipids

Lipids containing carbohydrate apart from Fatty acid and Alcohol (usually Sphingosine).

Faty Acid + Alcohol (Sphingosine) + Carbohydrate, e.g. Cerebroside, Ganglioside.

questions.text: After 2 days of penicillin administration, drug induced antibodies resulted in hemolysis. This is an example of which type of hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Drug induced hemolysis is an example of type 2 HSR

  • High dose Penicillin can induce immune mediated hemolysis via the hapten mechanism in which antibodies are targeted against the combination of penicillin in association with red blood cells.
  • Complement is activated by the attached antibody leading to the removal of red blood cells by the spleen.
  • This is an example of drug induced type-II hypersensitivity reaction.
  • Type 2 HSR MNEMONIC;
  • My-Myasthenia Gravis
  • Blood-Blood Transfusion Reaction
  • Group-Goodpasture Syndrome, Grave's Disease
  • Is-Immune Hemolytic Anemia, Immune thrombocytopenic
  • RH-RH Incompatibility, Rheumatic heart disease
  • Positive - Pemphigus (Bullous), Pernicious Anemia

questions.text: Horizontal transmission of 'R' factor is by:
questions.solution:
R factor is plasmid which is transferred by conjugation

Conjugation; A process where genetic elements (F factor or chromosomal material) is transferred from donor bacterium to recipient bacterium by making physical contact through sex pilus

  • R factor (or the resistance factor) is a plasmid which has two components.
    • Resistance transfer factor (RTF) is the plasmid responsible for conjugational transfer (similar to F factor)
    • Resistance determinant (r): Codes for resistance to one drug
    • An R factor can have several r determinants so it is more dangerous and difficult to treat than mutational drug resistance which is due to single mutation.

INCORRECT OPTION:

  • Transduction: Transduction is defined as transmission of a portion of DNA from one bacterium to another by a bacteriophage (virus infecting bacteria)
  • Transformation: taking up soluble DNA fragments across their cell wall from other species
  • a process where two bacteria combine their cell walls and membranes to share cellular contents, such as proteins and RNA

questions.text: All of the following are part of innate immunity EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
• Immunity against infectious diseases is mainly of two types: Innate and acquired(adaptive).
  • Innate immunity: This provides the first line of defence against infections. It is the resistance to infections that an individual possesses by virtue of his or her genetic and constitutional make-up.
    • It is not affected by prior contact with microorganisms or immunization.
    • Innate immunity may be considered at the level of the species, race or individual.
  • Acquired or Adaptive immunity: The resistance that an individual acquires during life by recognising and selectively eliminating specific foreign molecules is known as acquired immunity.
  • This displays four characteristic features:
    • Antigen specificity
    • Diversity
    • Immunologic memory
    • Self/nonself recognition.

T-cells (cell mediated) and B-cells (humoral/antibody mediated) are part of acquired immunity.

Components of innate immunity:

choices.text: It is a variant of large lymphocyte
Antibody can enhance the effectiveness of NK cells

questions.text: Regarding NK cells, false statement is:
questions.solution:
• Null cells are large granular lymphocytes
  • 5-10% of circulating lymphocytes lack features of either T or B cells and known as Null cell/Natural Killer (NK) cell.
  • Pan-T cell marker (CD-3) and TCR absent. It does not require thymus for development.
  • Pan-B cell marker (CD-19) and IgM, IgD are absent
  • CD16+, CD 56+ and CD94 on surface of NK cells
  • IL 2 produced by macrophages, interferons alpha and beta produced by virus-infected cells acts as growth factor for NK cells. IL-2 is also a potent stimulator of NK cells.
  • NK cells can kill without antibody, but antibody (IgG) enhances their effectiveness: Antibody dependent cellular cytotoxicity (ADCC).

questions.text: CRISPR-Cas9 has revolutionized genomic DNA studies. Which of the following is true for CRISPR-Cas9?
questions.solution:
CRISPR-Cas9 (clustered regularly interspersed short palindromic repeats - associated gene 9)

Option A: RISPR-Cas9 is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique.

Option B & Option C: CRISPR-Cas9 is a RNA-directed site specific endonuclease.

Option D: CAS9 is CRISPR associated protein 9, has an endonuclease enzyme activity which used CRISPR sequences as a guide. Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR-Cas9

It is a novel Gene editing or gene regulatory technique

It was recognized by Emmanuelle Charpentier and Jennifer Doudna (awarded Nobel Prize in Chemistry in 2020).

CRISPR: clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats

  • CRISPR found in genomes of prokaryotic organisms (in bacteria and archaea).

It found in approximately 50% of sequenced bacterial genomes and 90% of sequenced archaea.

  • These sequences are originally derived from DNA fragments of bacteriophages that had previously infected the prokaryote.

Later they are used by prokaryotes to detect and destroy DNA from similar bacteriophages during subsequent infections to prokaryotes.

So these sequences play role as an antiviral (antiphase) defense system for prokaryotes and provide an acquired or adaptive immunity to prevent reinfection of a bacterium by specific bacteriophages

  • CRISPR complements the system of restriction endonucleases and methylases. CRISPR uses RNA-based targeting to bring the Cas9 nuclease to foreign (or any complementary) DNA.

CAS9: CRISPR associated protein 9

  • An endonuclease enzyme
  • It uses CRISPR sequences as a guide (as guide RNA).
  • Then recognizes specific DNA strands that are complementary to CRISPR sequence & cleave them.

CRISPR CAS9

  • Both together are used to edit genes within organisms.
  • Within bacteria this CRISPR-RNA-Cas9 complex then degrades and inactivates the targeted DNA.

The CRISPR system has been also adapted for use in eukaryotic cells, including human cells, where it has been shown to be an RNA-directed site-specific nuclease just as it is in bacteria.

  • It has wide varieties of application in medicine, in basic biological research, food and farming industries.

In medicine, it was used experimentally to treat a patient with a genetic disorder (e.g. sickle cell disease), to treat viral infection like HIV etc.

  • Variations on the use of CRISPR allow for gene deletion, gene editing, gene visualization, and even modulation of gene transcription in basic biological research.

Thus, CRISPR has added an exciting new, highly efficient, and very specific technology to the toolbox of methods for the manipulation of DNA and genetic analysis of mammalian cells.

  • A variant of the CRISPR-Cas system, C2c2, has been shown to site-specifically cleave RNA. This exciting discovery paves the way for potential specific alteration of mRNA levels in human cells.

questions.text: The retroviruses (eg, HIV virus) are transcribed by reverse transcriptase enzymes, to produce a double-stranded DNA copy of their RNA genome. This viral reverse transcriptase enzyme is:
questions.solution:
The genetic material for some animal and plant viruses is RNA rather than DNA. Many animal RNA viruses specifically, the retroviruses (eg, the human immunodeficiency, or HIV virus) are transcribed by viral RNA dependent DNA polymerase, the so-called reverse transcriptase, to produce a double-stranded DNA copy of their RNA genome. In many cases, the resulting double-stranded DNA transcript is integrated into the host genome and subsequently serves as a template for gene expression and from which new viral RNA genomes and viral mRNAs can be transcribed. Genomic insertion of such integrating "proviral" DNA molecules can, depending on the site involved, be mutagenic, inactivating a gene or disregulating its expression.

So Option A is correct, Option B, Option C and Option D are incorrect.

choices.text: Asymptomatic in females and acute urethritis in males
Acute cervicitis in female and acute urethritis in males

questions.text: The most common presentation of N. Gonorrhea is:
questions.solution:
The most common presentation of N. Gonorrhea is Asymptomatic in females and acute urethritis in males.

Clinical Manifestations of N.Gonorrhoeae are:

  1. Asymptomatic in women(but still infectious)
  2. Men: urethritis
  3. Women: cervical gonorrhea, which can progress to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) Complications of PID
    1. Sterility
    2. Ectopic pregnancy
    3. Abscess
    4. Peritonitis
    5. Perihepatitis
  4. Both men and women:
    1. Gonococcal bacteremia
    2. Septic arthritis: gonococcal arthritis is the most common cause of septic arthritis in sexually active individuals.
  5. Neonates: Ophthalmia neonatorum conjunctivitis in newborns. N. gonorrhoeae is acquired during passage through an infected birth canal. Conjunctivitis usually erupts within the first 5 days.

Possible complications of this infection include epididymitis, prostatitis, and urethral strictures. Fortunately, this disease is easily cured by a small dose of ceftriaxone.

Men having sex with men (referred to as MSM) results in rectal gonococcal infection and this is often the only site of infection in this group. This infection is usually asymptomatic but can cause anal pruritis, tenesmus, and/or rectal bleeding and purulent discharge.

Superficial blebs or bullae may form later.

  • Recurrences are common, occurring after many years, involving the same site.

D)Ecthyma :Deeper /ulcerative variant of impetigo.Purulent, irregular ulcer with chocolate brown ,thick adherent crust .Causative organism streptococci pyogenes.

Most common areas are lower extremites.

questions.text: Which of the following bacteria is associated with the production of a non-diffusible red pigment, leading to the appearance of pseudohemoptysis (red-colored sputum), often mistaken for blood?
questions.solution:
Serratia Marcescens is a normal soil saprophyte releasing a non-diffusing red pigment called Prodigiosin, which causes nosocomial UTI and Pneumonia. Due to its red pigment, it leads to pseudohemoptysis. The frequency of reports of healthcare-associated infections caused by S. marcescens is on the rise. These organisms contaminate IV fluids, surgical instruments and antiseptic solutions. The bacillus has been associated with meningitis, endocarditis, septicemia, peritonitis, respiratory infection and many other conditions. Multiple drug resistance is common in hospital strains.

Enterobacter is a normal GI bacteria, known to cause nosocomial infections

Citrobacter is a known nosocomial pathogen as well

Klebsiella ozaenae is known to cause secondary atrophic rhinitis

questions.text:
A patient presents with a history of fever and dry cough for 5 days. He started noticing a rash on his body on the 3rd day. On examination respiratory wheeze was heard. The rash of the patient was:

And chest X-ray of the patient was:Identify the incorrect statements of the causative agent in this patient.
a) The patient is a case of typical pneumonia.
b) It is most likely caused by PPLO.
c) It is popularly known as walking pneumonia.
d) It has a peptidoglycan cell wall.
e) It is very sensitive to beta lactam antibiotics.
f) Is an obligate intracellular organism.
questions.solution:
The chest x-ray shows peribronchial pneumonia with bronchial thickening and streaks of interstitial infiltrates along with skin lesions showing erythema multiforme major. This indicates the patient is having atypical pneumonia caused by mycoplasma pneumoniae.

  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae causes "atypical" community acquired interstitial pneumonia similar to pneumonia caused by other agents, such as Chlamydophila pneumoniae, Legionella pneumophila and viral pneumonia.
  • Pneumonia is mild, it is also known as walking pneumonia.
  • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is a fastidious, slow-growing bacterium that lacks a cell wall, making it distinct from most other bacteria.
  • It is the causative agent of atypical pneumonia, often referred to as walking pneumonia.
  • Due to its lack of a cell wall, Mycoplasma pneumoniae is not susceptible to beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillin) but instead requires antibiotics like macrolides (e.g., azithromycin) or tetracyclines (e.g., doxycycline) for treatment.
  • Various manifestations include:
    • Neurologic: Meningoencephalitis, encephalitis, Guillain-Barre syndrome and aseptic meningitis.
    • Dermatologic: Skin rashes including erythema multiforme major(Stevens-Johnson syndrome).
    • Cardiac: Myocarditis, pericarditis.
    • Rheumatologic: Reactive arthritis.
    • Hematologic: Anemia and hypercoagulopathy.
  • They are free living in the environment.
  • They can grow on artificial cell-free culture media.
  • It is best cultured on specialized media such as PPLO agar (Pleuropneumonia-like organism agar) or agar with yeast extract.

questions.text: The most common species causing the following clinical picture in men is:
questions.solution:
• Actinomyces are soil saprophytes and commensals of the oral cavity.
  • In humans, they cause actinomycosis.
  • A.israelii is the most common species infecting man.
  • Actinomycosis is a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection characterized by multiple abscesses with formation of sinuses, discharge containing granules and on later stage; fibrosis and tissue destruction.

questions.text: Beta lactam antibiotics resistance in staphylococcus is transferred by:
questions.solution: β-lactamase or penicillinase enzymes cleave the β-lactam rings, and thereby organisms producing these enzymes develop resistance to β-lactam antibiotics. This resistance is plasmid coded, and can be transferred between S. aureus strains by transduction.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male, Rajendra, presents with a rash on his torso as shown below. He was taking immunosuppressants for managing his kidney transplant. What is the most common cause of death in patients associated with this organism?
questions.solution:
Most common cause of fever with rash in a, immunocompromised patient is reactivation of varicella-Shingles.

Incorrect options;

A &b) secondary bacterial infection and meningitis are one of complications of shingles but it is not common cause of death.

Secondary bacterial infection is most common complication of varicella zoster infection.

d)myocarditis is usually not seen in shingles, it is complication of Corynebacterium.

questions.text: Which of the following contains abnormal infectious protein molecules without nucleic acid?
questions.solution:
• Prions are infectious protein molecules without nucleic acid, which are highly resistant to physical and chemical agents.
  • The causative agent of scrapie Kuru Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
  • It has been shown to be a small particle (MW 50,000 and probably 4-6nm in diameter), without any detectable nucleic acid, resistant to heat (90 degree C for three minutes), UV rays and nucleases, and sensitive to proteases.
  • Prions cause slow and delayed infections in humans having a long incubation period called prion disease (brain neurodegenerative condition).

Other Options:

  • Viruses (A): contain nucleic acid (either DNA or RNA) encapsulated in a protein coat.
  • Viroid(B): The term ‘viroid’ was introduced by Diener to describe a new class of subviral agents characterised by the apparent absence of an extracellular dormant phase (virion) and by a genome much smaller than those of known viruses.

The infective agent is protein free, low molecular weight RNA resistant to heat and organic solvents but sensitive to nucleases.

First identified in the potato spindle tuber disease, viroids have been shown to cause some plant diseases also.

  • Virusoids(C): circular RNA without proteins, but dependent on plant viruses for replication

questions.text: An infant was vaccinated with Measles vaccine at 7th month of age, due to close contact during a Measles outbreak. When should the next doses be administered to this infant?
questions.solution:
The Edmonston Zagreb strain is used to prepare vaccines against Measles.

In the National Immunisation Schedule, vaccine for Measles is given at 9th month, followed by one more dose between 16-24th month.

In case of an outbreak of Measles, vaccine can be given anytime after the 6th month. However, the normal vaccination schedule should be followed duly.

Edmonston Zagreb strain: Measles vaccine. A safe and effective live attenuated measles vaccine is available. The original live vaccines used the Edmonston strain developed by multiple passage through human kidney, amnion and chick embryo cultures. Due to its high risk of causing febrile rash (vaccination measles), further attenuation became necessary. The Schwartz and Moraten strains so developed were safe but effective only in children older than 15 months. In the tropics, measles is common and serious in children below 12 months. Therefore the Edmonston-Zagreb strain, attenuated by passage in human diploid cells, is preferred because it is able to produce seroconversion even in infants 4-6 months old. The recommended age for measles vaccination in developing countries is now nine months, while in the advanced nations it remains 15 months.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man with chronic hepatitis B is undergoing treatment with entecavir. After 12 months of therapy, his viral load starts to increase despite adherence to the medication. Genotypic resistance testing reveals a mutation in the HBV surface antigen (HBsAg) gene that allows the virus to evade immune recognition. Which of the following is most likely responsible for the increase in viral load in this patient?
questions.solution:
Escape mutation:

-Escape mutations in HBV are genetic changes in the HBV surface antigen (HBsAg), which allow the virus to evade immune surveillance. These mutations alter the virus's ability to be recognized by antibodies or immune cells targeting HBsAg.

-Such mutations are particularly relevant in chronic hepatitis B patients who have been on long-term antiviral treatment like entecavir, where the virus can develop mechanisms to escape immune detection despite ongoing therapy.

A) YMDD mutation: YMDD mutation is a well-known mutation associated with resistance to nucleoside analogs like lamivudine, adefovir, and telbivudine. It affects the reverse transcriptase enzyme of the virus, not the HBsAg gene, and would typically be found in patients treated with these specific drugs.

C) Pre-core Mutants: They have defect in pre-core region of C gene which leads to their inability to synthesize HBeAg.

questions.text: Identify the type of haemorrhage shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
• An EDH is a collection of blood between the calvaria and outer (periosteal) layer of the dura. EDHs are biconvex in shape. Adherence of the periosteal dura to the inner calvaria explains this typical configuration.
  • As EDHs expand, they strip the dura away from the inner table of the skull, forming the classic lens-shaped hematoma.
  • Because the dura is especially tightly attached to sutures, EDHs in adults rarely cross suture lines (10% of EDHs in children do cross sutures, especially if a fracture traverses the suture or sutural diastasis is present).

Tuberculosis is acid fast with 20% sulphuric acid.

questions.text: Identify the type of injury
questions.solution:
• The given image shows an abrasion.
  • An abrasion (gravel rash) is a destruction of the skin, which usually involves only the superficial layers of the epidermis.
  • An abrasion is the most superficial ;of all the injuries.
  • It does not penetrate the full thickness of the epidermis.
  • They are caused by friction against a rough surface or by compression, such as a lateral rubbing action by a glancing blow, a fall on a rough surface, by being dragged in a vehicular accident, fingernails, thorns or teeth bite.
  • Most abrasions are caused by a lateral rubbing action.
  • If sufficient friction is applied, partial or complete removal of the epithelium may occur, and the superficial layer of dermis is damaged.
  • Many abrasions have some deeper areas of subepidermal damage which may result in superficial scarring.
  • Sometimes, full thickness of the skin may be damaged in places, but usually in an interrupted, irregular manner, and intact epidermis remains within the area of the abrasion.
  • A pure abrasion does not bleed, as blood vessels are confined to the dermis. However, the dermal papillae are corrugated in nature.
  • Thus, many abrasions enter the dermis and bleeding commonly occurs.

questions.text: The fertilisation of two ova released at two different menstrual cycles refers to:
questions.solution:
The fertilisation of two ova released at two different menstrual cycles refers to super foetation.

  • SUPERFECUNDATION: Superfecundation is the fertilization of two or more ova from the same cycle by sperm from separate acts of sexual intercourse. Heteropaternal superfecundation occurs when two different males father fraternal twins. In common usage, the term superfecundation is often used instead of heteropaternal superfecundation.
  • SUPERFOETATION: Superfetation means the fertilization of an ovum from a subsequent ovulation in a woman who is already pregnant. Two fetuses are born either at the same time showing different stages of development, or two fully developed fetuses are born varying from 1-3 months.
  • FETUS PAPYRASEOUS (Fetus compressus): In twin pregnancy, one fetus may grow and develop more than other fetus. The second under-developed fetus may get compressed and flattened. Such fetus is termed as fetus papyraseous
  • FECUNDATION AB EXTRA: Fertilisation of ova by the semen deposited on vulva or inner aspect of the thigh.

questions.solution: Hemodialysis is a treatment to filter wastes and water from the blood, as the kidneys do when they were healthy. Hemodialysis helps control blood pressure and balance important minerals, such as potassium, sodium, and calcium, in blood.

questions.text: Carbon monoxide poisoning causes
questions.solution:
CO combines reversibly with haemoglobin to form carboxyhemoglobin (COHb) producing anaemic hypoxia (Blood O2-carrying capacity is reduced).

  • It has a high affinity for Hb (about 250 times more than O2).
  • It inhibits electron transport by blocking cytochrome A3 oxidase and cytochrome P450 and hence intracellular respiration.

Anaemic hypoxia occurs when the oxygen carrying ability of the blood decreases, and thus, this defect is specifically associated with the blood. This implies that fewer hemoglobin molecules (or oxygen-binding sites) are available for binding oxygen.

• The clamp is used in myomectomy operation.

questions.text: Vaginal epithelium is derived from:
questions.solution:
Development of vagina is composite, partly from the mullerian ducts (paramesonephric ducts) and partly from the urogenital sinus.

Vaginal Epithelium

Vagina is lined by stratified squamous epithelium which is composed of the following types of cells:

  • Parabasal/basal cells: Which are predominant when there is no hormonal dominance.
  • Intermediate cells: Which are predominant when there is progesterone predominance, i.e. in luteal phase/latter half of the menstrual cycle.
  • Superficial cells: Which are predominant when there is estrogen predominance, i.e. in follicular phase-first half of the menstrual cycle.
  • The intermediate and superficial cells contain glycogen under the influence of estrogen. In Newborn females, vagina is lined by transitional epithelium.

questions.text: One of the following forms the basis for sex chromatin testing:
questions.solution:
Barr body forms the basis for sex chromatin testing.

Barr Body

When two X chromosomes are present in a cell (as in a normal female) one of them becomes inactivated and condensed on the nuclear membrane and is called the ‘Barr body'.

This process is termed as X chromosome lionization (inactivation) Presence or absence of Barr bodies helps in ascertaining the sex of an individuals

  • Absence of Barr body indicates that the patient has only one X chromosome (eg. Normal male XY or Turner's syndrome (XO)
  • Nuclei of cells in females (XX) contain a darkly staining Barr body that is not present in the nuclei of cells in males.
  • Barr bodies are most easily seen in a smear of squamous epithelial cells obtained by scraping the buccal mucosa
  • Barr bodies react differently to histological stains and are best seen as dark staining bodies within the nucleus of non-dividing interphase cells.

questions.text: Carcinoma endometrium with Para-aortic lymph node status is classified as stage:
A 19-year-old patient complains of primary amen- orrhea. She had well developed breast and pub- lic hair but on examination there was absence of uterus and vagina. Likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• In the question, a 19 year old girl is presenting with primary amenorrhea, she has well developed breast and public hair but on examination uterus and vagina are absent. Since her breast and public hair both are well developed- this means her secondary sexual characteristics are well developed.
  • This means that this female amount of estrogen is adequate, which means she has normally functioning ovaries.
  • Thus, options XYY (presence of Y Chromosome means- gonads are testis), Klienfelter's syndrome (genotype = 47XXY- again since Y chromosome is present, gonads are testes i.e. they are males) are ruled out and in gonadal dysgenesis- gonads are incompletely formed and are streak gonads, M/c example is Turner's syndrome - genotype 45XO. Since gonads are streak, therefore estrogen is insufficient so secondary sexual characteristics are not well developed. In Turners thus by exclusion, our answer is option b- i.e. Mayer Rokitansky kuster hauser syndrome.
  • "Patients with mullerian agenesis, typically present in late adolescence or as young adults, well after menarche was expected, with primary amenorrhea as their only complaint. They exhibit normal, symmetrical breast and public hair development, no usable vagina and have no symptoms or signs of cryptomenorrhea because the rudimentary uterus contains no functional endometrium."

questions.text: Which layer of myometrium is described as 'living ligature' of uterus
questions.solution:
3 layers of uterus

  • Endometrium
  • Myometrium
  • Perimetrium/serosal

Layers of myometrium

  • Outer longitudinal
  • Middle interlacing
  • Inner circular

The middle layer is the thickest of the three and consists of bundles of muscle separated by connective tissue. There is a tendency for the muscle bundles to interlace, and as the blood vessels which supply the uterus are distributed in the connective tissues, the caliber of the vessels is in part controlled by the contraction of the muscle cells. The purpose of this layer is therefore in part hemostatic. This layer is described as living ligatures of the uterus, and is responsible for control of bleeding in the third stage of labor.

Dermoid cyst: Dermoid cyst is a benign teratoma.

  • Most common benign neoplasm diagnosed during pregnancy. Most common Germ cell tumor.

It is the commonest tumor to undergo torsion.

If teeth or bone are seen in X-ray in adnexal mass, this finding is pathognomic for teratoma and thus X-ray is diagnostic.

choices.text: Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division
1st polar body is extruded during 1st meiotic division of primary oocytes
Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 1st meiotic division
Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 2nd meiotic division

questions.text: True statement regarding oogenesis are all except:
questions.solution:
The correct answer is:

C) Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 1st meiotic division

This statement is false because the secondary oocyte arrests in metaphase of the second meiotic division, not the first.

Let's analyze each statement:

A) Primary oocyte arrests in prophase of 1st meiotic division

  • True: This statement is correct. Primary oocytes arrest in the prophase of the first meiotic division and remain arrested until puberty.

B) 1st polar body is extruded during 1st meiotic division of primary oocytes

  • True: This statement is correct. During the first meiotic division of primary oocytes, the first polar body is extruded, along with a secondary oocyte.

C) Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 1st meiotic division

  • False: This statement is not true. The secondary oocyte does not arrest in metaphase of the first meiotic division. It continues into metaphase of the second meiotic division.

D) Secondary oocyte arrest in metaphase of 2nd meiotic division

  • True: This statement is correct. The secondary oocyte does arrest in metaphase of the second meiotic division until fertilization occurs.

The process involved in the development of mature ovum is called Oogenesis.

Oogenesis Process:

  1. Initiation of Oogenesis: Oogenesis is the process of forming female gametes, known as oocytes, from Primordial Germ Cells (PGCs). This process begins long before birth and takes place in the cortex of the ovary.
  2. PGC Division: PGCs undergo mitotic division to produce a large number of cells called oogonia.
  3. Formation of Primary Oocyte: Each oogonium enlarges to become a primary oocyte.
  4. Prophase of 1st Meiotic Division: The primary oocyte enters the prophase of the first meiotic division before birth. However, this division is arrested until puberty due to the presence of an oocyte maturation inhibitor (OMI) factor secreted by the follicular cells surrounding the oocyte.
  5. Completion of 1st Meiotic Division: The first meiotic division is completed only when primary oocytes start maturing and preparing for ovulation.
  6. Puberty and Ovulation: At puberty, during each ovarian cycle, 5-50 primary oocytes resume their first meiotic division, which is completed just before ovulation. This division results in two daughter cells, one of which is a secondary oocyte, and the other is the first polar body.
  7. Formation of Secondary Oocyte: The secondary oocyte enters the second meiotic division at the time of ovulation. However, this division is completed only after a sperm has penetrated the secondary oocyte. The second meiotic division is also unequal, resulting in one daughter cell receiving most of the cytoplasm and forming the ovum, while the other daughter cell receives a minimal amount of cytoplasm and forms the second polar body.
  8. Final Outcome: From one primary oocyte, only one ovum with 22 autosomes and one X chromosome is formed, along with three polar bodies, each containing 22 autosomes and one X chromosome.
  9. This process of oogenesis is crucial for the production of female gametes and is tightly regulated by hormonal and physiological factors throughout a woman's reproductive life.

questions.text:
Brain biopsy of a patient showed following:

He had complaints of difficulty in swallowing liquids, loss of appetite and restlessness. His history is significant for a dog bite a week ago. Which of the following schedules is not a part of the PEP regimen for this disease.
questions.solution:
• The photo shows Negri bodies (intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusion with characteristic basophilic inner granules, composed of rabies virus proteins and viral RNA).
  • The patient is most likely to have Rabies infection considering the dog bite and Negri bodies in brain biopsy.

There are various vaccination schedules for Rabies:

  • For post exposure prophylaxis:
    • ID regimens are cost effective; dose-sparing and time-sparing and therefore are preferred over IM regimens
    • ID regimen is known as THAI regimen;
    • 2 site ID given on 0, 3, 7, 28
    • IM regimen is known as ESSEN regimen;
    • 1 site IM given on 0, 3, 7, 14, 28
  • PEP for Individuals Previously Vaccinated (PrEP or PEP):
    • 1-site ID vaccine given on days 0 and 3 or
    • 1-site IM vaccine given on days 0 and 3 or
    • 4-site ID vaccine given on day 0 only (left and right deltoids, thigh or suprascapular areas).

Note: If repeat exposure occurs within 3 months of receiving PEP, only local wound treatment is required; neither vaccine nor RIG are needed.

  • Pre-exposure Prophylaxis (PrEP):
    • 2-site ID vaccine given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28
    • 1-site IM vaccine given on days 0, 7 and 21 or 28

questions.text: The best time to do chorionic villus sampling is:
questions.solution:
'CVS is the second most common procedure for genetic prenatal diagnosis. Because this procedure is routinely performed at about 10 to 12 weeks of gestation, it allows for an earlier detection of abnormalities and a safer pregnancy termination, if desired.'

'CVS is usually performed between 11 and 14 weeks.' -Williams 24/ e, p 300

Advantages over amniocentesis:

  • The main advantage of CVS is that results are available earlier in pregnancy, which allows earlier and safer methods of pregnancy termination when results are abnormal.

Risks:

  • Chances of fetal loss/abortion 1-2% (more than amniocentesis).
  • If performed earlier than 9 weeks (typically around 7 weeks), increased chances of oromandibular limb hypogenesis and limb reduction defects.
  • It can cause rupture of membranes, leakage of amniotic fluid and infection.
  • Rh isoimmunization can occur in Rh-negative females.

questions.text: Best parameter for estimation of fetal age by ultrasound in 3rd trimester is:

choices.text: Xanthine oxidase reaction can form superoxide
Superoxide dismutase enzyme present in both mitochondria and cytoplasm
Superoxide dismutase protects anaerobic organisms against oxygen toxicity
Superoxide acts as both oxidant and reductant

questions.text: All of the following is true regarding superoxide, except:
questions.solution:
• Option A: Superoxide is formed when reduced flavins present (for example, in xanthine oxidase reaction)
  • Option B: Superoxide dismutase enzyme occurs in all major aerobic tissues in the mitochondria and the cytosol.
  • Option C: Superoxide dismutase protects aerobic organisms against oxygen toxicity
  • Option D: Superoxide can reduce oxidized cytochrome c, which catalyzes the conversion of superoxide to oxygen and hydrogen peroxide.

O2- + Cyt c (Fe+3) → O2 + Cyt c (Fe+2)

In this reaction, superoxide acts as both oxidant and reductant.

Superoxide & Superoxide dismutase

  • Transfer of a single electron to O2 generates the potentially damaging superoxide anion free radical (O2- ) which gives rise to free-radical chain reactions and amplifying its destructive effects.
  • Such superoxide can be formed from oxygen in tissues easily.
  • So, the presence of superoxide dismutase (SOD) enzyme is responsible for its removal in all aerobic organisms (although not in obligate anaerobes) and prevent the potential toxicity of oxygen is due to its conversion to superoxide.
  • Superoxide is formed when reduced flavins present (for example, in xanthine oxidase reaction) and it is reoxidized univalently by molecular oxygen:

Enz - Flavin - H2 + O2 → Enz - Flavin - H + O2- + H+

  • Superoxide can reduce oxidized cytochrome c, which catalyzes the conversion of superoxide to oxygen and hydrogen peroxide

O2- + Cyt c (Fe+3) → O2 + Cyt c (Fe+2)

  • In this reaction, superoxide acts as both oxidant and reductant. Thus, superoxide dismutase protects aerobic organisms against the potential deleterious effects of superoxide.
  • The enzyme occurs in all major aerobic tissues in the mitochondria and the cytosol.
  • An exposure of animals to an atmosphere of 100% oxygen causes prolonged exposure leads to lung damage by superoxide and can lead to death.
  • It will also increase in SOD as an adaptive response particularly in the lungs. Other antioxidants, for example, α-tocopherol (vitamin E), act as scavengers of free radicals and reduce the toxicity of oxygen.

questions.text: Match the correct option with the layers of a mask as shown in figure:
questions.solution:
The mask shown in figure has three layers

  1. Outer fluid repellent layer: Hydrophobic layer that can repel water, blood and body fluids.
  2. Middle filter layer: It is made up of melt-blown material; filters bacteria/viruses and also filters out the water droplets. In contrast to N95 respirator, the filter pore size of a surgical mask is not standardized.
  3. Inner hydrophilic layer: Absorbs water, sweat and spit; made up of non-woven fabric.

When using a surgical mask, the following measures should be considered:

  • Shelf-life: Disposable (single-use); should be discarded or changed after 4-6 hours of use or earlier if it becomes soiled or wet.
  • Donning: Place the mask carefully, ensuring it covers the mouth and nose, adjust to the nose bridge, and tie it securely to minimize any gaps between the face and the mask.
  • Hanging mask syndrome: Masks should not be left dangling around the neck, a common practice observed among doctors, doing so may contaminate the inner side of mask.
  • Touching the front of the mask while wearing should be avoided.
  • Mask should not be worn with beard or unshaven face.
  • Hand hygiene should be performed before donning the mask, upon touching or discarding a used mask.

questions.text: Which cardinal movements occur during labour?
questions.solution:
Series of events that take place in the genital organs in an effort to expel the viable products of conception out of the womb through the vagina into the outer world is called Labour.

Mechanism of normal labour is defined as the manner in which the fetus adjusts itself to pass through the parturient canal with minimal difficulty.

There are 8 cardinal movements of the head in normal labour.

  • Every - Engagement (Synclitic or Asynclitic)
  • Decent - Descent
  • Female - Flexion
  • I - Internal rotation
  • Choose to - Crowning
  • Employ - Extension
  • Rises - Restitution
  • Extremely - External rotation

Mnemonic : Every Decent Female I Choose to and Employ Rises Extremely.

questions.text: In heart disease, prophylactic forceps is applied at head station of:
questions.solution:
• In heart disease forceps are applied prophylactically to cut down the second stage of labour and usually low or outlet forceps are applied.
    • Low forceps: Applied when the leading point of the fetal scalp is at station + 2 and not on the pelvic floor.
    • Outlet forceps: Applied when fetal skull has reached pelvic floor and scalp is visible at the introitus even without separating the labia, i.e. station³ + 3

Note: 'O' station means the level of ischial spine.

questions.text: What is the metabolic defect in Primary Oxaluria Type II?
questions.solution:
Primary Hyperoxaluria Type I

  • The most common form of Primary hyperoxaluria.
  • It is due to a deficiency of the peroxisomal enzyme alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase, (expressed only in the liver peroxisomes and requires pyridoxine (vitamin B6) as its cofactor)
  • Protein targeting defect.

Primary Hyperoxaluria Type II (Glyceric Aciduria)

  • Due to a deficiency of D-glycerate dehydrogenase (glyoxylate reductase enzyme complex)

Secondary Hyperoxaluria

  • Pyridoxine deficiency (cofactor for alanine-glyoxylate aminotransferase)
  • After ingestion of ethylene glycol
  • High doses of vitamin C
  • After administration of the anesthetic agent metho- xyPurane (which oxidizes directly to oxalic acid)
  • In patients with inflammatory bowel disease or extensive resection of the bowel (enteric hyperoxaluria).

Nonketotic Hyperglycemia

  • Due to a defect in the Glycine Cleavage System

questions.text: Km is the substrate concentration at which:
questions.solution:
The Michaelis-Menten equation illustrates in mathematical terms the relationship between initial reaction velocity vi and substrate concentration [S].

The Michaelis constant Km is the substrate concentration at which vi is half the maximal velocity (Vmax/2) attainable at a particular concentration of the enzyme.

questions.text: True about isoenzymes is:
questions.solution:
Isozymes are distinct enzyme forms that catalyze the same reaction.

Higher organisms often elaborate several physically distinct versions of a given enzyme, each of which catalyzes the same reaction.

Like the members of other protein families, these protein catalysts or isozymes arise through gene duplication.

While the proteases described above have different substrates, isozymes may possess subtle differences in properties such as sensitivity to particular regulatory factors or substrate affinity (eg, hexokinase and glucokinase) that adapt them to specific tissues or circumstances rather than distinct substrate specificities. Isozymes that catalyze the identical reaction may also enhance survival by providing a 'backup' copy of an essential enzyme.

  • Isoenzymes catalyse the same reaction. For example, LDH1-5 all convert Pyruvate to lactate
  • They have different quaternary structure. For example, the subunits in LDH-1 is different from LDH-2
  • Tissue distribution of each isoform is different
  • Enzyme name and number can be different.

questions.text: A patient who was treated for an MRSA abscess and discharged is seen for a follow-up appointment. Upon examination, he is found to be a nasal carrier of MRSA. The most appropriate treatment for nasal carriers of MRSA is?
questions.solution:
Single most effective method of prevention of hospital acquired infections is handwashing.

DOC in the treatment of MRSA is vancomycin.

Nasal carriers of Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) can be treated with Mupirocin 2% ointment. Mupirocin is a topical antibiotic that is effective in eradicating MRSA from the nasal passages, which are a common site for colonization. It is typically applied to both nostrils for a period of 5 to 10 days.

(A): Chlorhexidine: While chlorhexidine is an antiseptic used for skin cleaning and disinfection, it is not specifically indicated for the treatment of nasal MRSA carriage.

(B): Rifampicin: Rifampicin is an antibiotic used to treat certain systemic infections, but it is not typically used alone for decolonization of MRSA in nasal carriers.

(D): Ethyl alcohol: Ethyl alcohol (e.g., isopropyl alcohol) is an antiseptic commonly used for disinfecting the skin, but it does not target MRSA colonization in the nasal passages.

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that is done to limit the spread of infection in HIV patients?
questions.solution:
Evisceration Methods (Techniques of autopsy):

  1. Letulle's techniquw:
    • Described by Letulle.
    • Also known as, 'En masse' or 'En bloc' dissection
    • En masse = In a group; all together
    • En bloc = All together or all at the same time
    • In this technique, oral, cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one large organ block.
    • Leaves all attachments intact.
    • Commonly done in medical colleges to teach students
  2. Virchow's Method:
    • Organ by organ removal
    • Individual organ removal one by one.
    • Subsequent dissection of isolated organs.
    • Useful for assessing individual organ pathology.
    • Quick and effective for single organ focus.
    • Most common method in India
  3. Gohn's technique:
    • Developed by Ghon.
    • Also known as, 'Block by block' dissection
    • Cervical & thoracic organs, abdominal organs and the urogenital system are removed as separate organ blocks.
  4. In Situ Dissection:
    • Developed by Rokitansky.
    • Also known as In-situ dissection
    • Organs dissected in situ with minimal evisceration.
    • Rarely performed.
    • Done in infected & suspected infection cases.

questions.text: In the court of law, the act of witness giving false evidence after taking oath is punishable under:
questions.solution:
The act of witness giving false evidence after taking oath is known as Perjury, which is punishable under Sec. 229 BNS.

Important BNS sections related to false evidence and false certificates.

227 → Giving false evidence (Perjury) - Definition

228 → Fabricating false evidence - Definition

229 → Punishment for Sec. 227 and 228 BNS (Up to 7 years of imprisonment)

234 → Issuing or signing false certificate - Punishment is same as for giving false evidence

  • Sec. 227 BNS - Giving false evidence (PERJURY): Whoever, being legally bound by an oath or by an express provision of law to state the truth, or being bound by law to make a declaration upon any subject, makes any statement which is false, and which he either knows or believes to be false or does not believe to be true, is said to give false evidence.
  • Sec. 228 BNS - Fabricating false evidence: Whoever causes any circumstance to exist or makes any false entry in any book or record, or electronic record or makes any document or electronic record containing a false statement, intending that such circumstance, false entry or false statement may appear in evidence in a judicial proceeding, or in a proceeding taken by law before a public servant as such, or before an arbitrator, and that such circumstance, false entry or false statement, so appearing in evidence, may cause any person who in such proceeding is to form an opinion upon the evidence, to entertain an erroneous opinion touching any point material to the result of such proceeding is said "to fabricate false evidence".
  • Sec. 229 BNS - Punishment for false evidence: (1) Whoever intentionally gives false evidence in any stage of a judicial proceeding, or fabricates false evidence for the purpose of being used in any stage of a judicial proceeding, shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to seven years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to ten thousand rupees. (2) Whoever intentionally gives or fabricates false evidence in any case other than that referred to in sub-section (1), shall be punished with imprisonment of either description for a term which may extend to three years, and shall also be liable to fine which may extend to five thousand rupees.
  • Sec. 234 BNS - Issuing or signing false certificate: Whoever issues or signs any certificate required by law to be given or signed, or relating to any fact of which such certificate is by law admissible in evidence, knowing or believing that such certificate is false in any material point, shall be punished in the same manner as if he gave false evidence.

Reference: The Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita, 2023

questions.text: Match the following plant poisons with their active principles

There is a history of village people consuming a crop as a staple diet. Many of the villagers are now presenting with paresis and are using a stick to stand. Which of the following vitamins would help?
questions.solution:
This is a case of "Osteolathyrism"

γ-glutamyl-β-aminopropionitrile(BAPN), a glutamine derivative of ß-aminopropionitrile in Lathyrus (Khesari dal) is a known osteolathyrogen. Vit C is protective against the effects of this molecule by strengthening the Collagen

Option A: Vitamin A deficiency is the most important preventable cause of blindness. The earliest sign of deficiency is a loss of sensitivity to green light, followed by impairment to adapt to dim light, then night blindness, an inability to see in the dark.

More prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia: keratinization of the cornea and blindness. Vitamin A also has an important role in differentiation of immune system cells, and even mild deficiency leads to increased susceptibility to infectious diseases. The synthesis of retinol-binding protein, which is required to transport the vitamin in the bloodstream, is reduced in response to infection(it is a negative acute phase protein), decreasing the circulating concentration of the vitamin and further impairing immune responses.

Option B: In the vitamin D deficiency disease rickets, the bones of children are under mineralized as a result of poor absorption of calcium. Similar problems occur as a result of deficiency during the adolescent growth spurt. Osteomalacia in adults results from the demineralization of bone, especially in women who have little exposure to sunlight, especially after several pregnancies.

Option C: Vitamin C deficiency can lead to scurvy. Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required for the postsynthetic modification of procollagen to collagen. Both this enzyme requires vitamin C. So signs of vitamin C deficiency include skin changes, fragility of blood capillaries, gum decay, tooth loss and bone fracture, which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis(leading to delayed wound healing) and psychological changes that can be attributed to impaired synthesis of catecholamines.

Option D: Vitamin K deficiency can lead to bleeding.

So This patient is likely to have Vitamin C deficiency.

questions.text: When do the following micronutrient deficiencies cause poor wound healing?
questions.solution:
Option A: Dietary deficiency of copper leads to Menkes syndrome. It is characterized by kinky hair and growth retardation. Copper is an essential cofactor for the enzyme lysyl oxidase that functions in formation of the covalent cross-links that strengthen collagen fiber. So deficiency of copper can cause poor wound healing.

Option B: Zinc deficiency can lead to Acrodermatitis Enteropathica. It is a genetic condition where Zn absorption is defective, which leads to Zn deficiency. Characterized by acrodermatitis(inflammation around mouth, nose, fingers etc), diarrhea, alopecia (loss of hair in discrete areas), ophthalmoplegia and hypogonadism.

Option C: Selenium deficiency may lead to cardiomyopathy, heart failure and striated muscle degeneration.

Option D: Iron deficiency can lead to microcytic anemia. Muscle abnormalities, koilonychia, ↓ work performance, impaired cognitive development, premature labor, ↑ perinatal maternal death are also seen.

questions.text: In an isolated mitochondria, in a medium containing Succinate, Fumarate, ADP and Pi, ATP were produced. Later a compound was added and oxidative phosphorylation was decreased. What's that compound?
questions.solution:
Option A: The antibiotic oligomycin completely blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by blocking the flow of protons through ATP synthase.

Option B: Uncouplers(e.g. dinitrophenol) are amphipathic and increase the permeability of the lipoid inner mitochondrial membrane to protons, thus reducing the electrochemical potential and short-circuiting the ATP synthase. In this way, oxidation can proceed without phosphorylation.

Option C: Antimycin A, dimercaprol & BAL inhibit the respiratory chain at Complex III.

Option D: Complex I is inhibited by Rotenone, Piericidin A.Barbiturates such as amobarbital also inhibit electron transport via Complex I by blocking the transfer from Fe-S to Q. At sufficiently high dosage, they are fatal.

questions.text: The condition shown in the figure is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Option A: Niacin deficiency can lead to pellagra. Pellagra is characterized by photosensitive dermatitis. As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrhea. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

Pellagra is common when the staple diet is maize, due to low tryptophan content & bound form of niacin which is unavailable to the body.

Pellagra is a multifactorial disease. Although the nutritional etiology of pellagra is well established and either tryptophan or niacin prevents or cures the disease, additional factors, including deficiency of riboflavin or vitamin B6, both of which are required for synthesis of nicotinamide from tryptophan, may be important. 

In most outbreaks of pellagra, twice as many women as men are affected, probably the result of inhibition of tryptophan metabolism by estrogen metabolites.

Option B & Option C: Contact dermatitis & Drug induced dermatitis not leading to above features.

Option D: In experimental animals, vitamin E deficiency results in resorption of fetuses and testicular atrophy. Dietary deficiency of vitamin E in human beings is unknown, although patients with severe fat malabsorption, cystic fibrosis and some forms of chronic liver disease suffer deficiency because they are unable to absorb or transport the vitamin, leading to nerve and muscle membrane damage. Premature infants are born with inadequate reserves of the vitamin. The erythrocyte membranes are abnormally fragile as a result of lipid peroxidation, leading to hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: A patient with PDA (Patent Ductus Arteriosus), Sensorineural hearing loss and cataract. Identify the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
• The clinical presentation of Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), sensorineural hearing loss, and cataract is characteristic of Congenital Rubella Syndrome.
  • Rubella Virus: Belongs to the togavirus family, an enveloped RNA virus. There is only one antigen type of the virus.
  • Transmission: Source of infection is typically subclinical infections.
  • Carrier Stage: There is no carrier stage in postnatally acquired rubella, but infants with congenital rubella can shed the virus for many months.
  • Incubation Period: Approximately 3-4 weeks.
  • Clinical Presentation: Congenital rubella syndrome presents with a triad of Patent Ductus Arteriosus (PDA), sensorineural hearing loss, and cataract.
  • Congenital Rubella Syndrome: Occurs when the rubella virus in the mother affects the developing baby, usually in the first three months of pregnancy. This syndrome can result in cataract, congenital heart disease, hearing impairment, and developmental delay.
  • Prevention: Cases of congenital rubella syndrome have dramatically decreased since the introduction of the rubella vaccine.
  • Congenital CMV - Most common congenital infection. Through Sexual contact or organ transplant. o C/P: Hearing loss, Seizures, Petechial rash, Chorioretinitis, Periventricular calcification.
  • Congenital Toxoplasmosis: Maternal risk factors - Raw or undercooked meat, Unwashed produce (ie, contaminated soil), Handling of cat feces.
  • Clinical features
  • Classic triad: Chorioretinitis, Hydrocephalus, Diffuse intracranial calcifications
  • Seizures
  • Microcephaly (brain atrophy) or macrocephaly (severe hydrocephalus)
  • Nonspecific findings: jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly, rash, growth restriction.

Congenital syphilis - Early - Snuffles: copious clear, purulent, or serosanguineous rhinorrhea.

Rash: diffuse maculopapular or bullous Palms, soles, buttocks, legs usually involved

Desquamation & hyperpigmentation

Long bone abnormalities (eg, metaphyseal lucencies)

Late: Saddle nose, notched (Hutchinson) teeth, saber shins, sensorineural hearing loss.

questions.text: During a radiological examination, a radiologist identifies a bullet present in the body surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. What type of bullet is it called?
questions.solution:
The kind of bullet identified by the radiologist as explained in the given scenario is known as a souvenir bullet.

Souvenir bullet is the one which has been lodged in the body for a long time with no fresh bleeding around it and surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. They can be visualized on X-rays. They are usually a result of bullet lodging in an inaccessible space which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. E.g., Bullet in the spine.

Other options:

Tandem bullet(Piggyback bullet): The bullet may fail to be ejected and on firing second time, the second bullet may go off carrying the lodged bullet with it and both may enter the body through the same entrance wound or two different entrance wounds. This may be on account of some defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or where the loaded firearm has not been used for a considerable period or prolonged exposure to high environmental temperature or humidity.

Incendiary bullets: The tip of the bullet contains white phosphorous. Used to cause fire in the target(E.g., to ignite fuel tank).

questions.text: Identify the type of fracture?
questions.solution:
The given image shows multiple fracture lines dividing the skull into fragments. Hence it is mosaic fracture/spider web fracture/comminuted fracture of skull.

It is a comminuted fracture that also has fissures radiating from it, forming a spider's-web or mosaic pattern. These fractures are formed due to a significant force striking over a broad area.

Option (A): Depressed fracture (Signature fracture/fracture a la signature) is caused by blows from heavy weapon with a small striking surface. E.g., stone, stick, hammer, etc.

Option (C): Diastatic fractures occur when there is a separation of the cranial sutures, most commonly with the sagital suture

Option (D): Pond fracture/Indented fracture/Ping-pong ball fracture - May be seen in newborn or infants (skull is elastic). Usually produced by forcible compression of the skull by obstetric forceps or impact

questions.text: Patient presented with bony pain and proteinuria. Which metal is likely to be associated with it?
questions.solution:
Chronic poisoning by Cadmium manifests with painful bony lesions, proteinuria and golden yellow discoloration of teeth.

Signs and Symptoms of cadmium poisoning:

Toxicity by inhalation is far greater than by ingestion.

On inhalation: Symptoms develop usually after 4-8 hours. They are influenza-like and similar to those seen in metal fume fever. It is characterized by sneezing, sore throat, irritant cough, nausea, excessive salivation, metallic taste, headache and cyanosis ('cadmium blues'). After a latent period of 24-36 hours, chemical pneumonitis develops which is characterized by fever, dyspnoea, bronchospasm and pleuritic chest pain, along with tachycardia, oliguria and noncardiogenic pulmonary edema.

On ingestion: Symptoms occur in 1 hour. These are increased salivation, nausea, vomiting, cramps in the abdomen, diarrhoea, myalgia, collapse, and rarely death.

Chronic exposure: Causes anosmia, yellowing of teeth (cadmium ring formation), emphysema, bone pain, fractures with osteomalacia (itai-itai disease or ouch-ouch disease is the most severe form) and chronic renal failure (hypercalciuria, proteinuria, azotemia). In males, it decreases libido, fertility and serum testosterone level, and in females, the function of ovary and development of oocytes may be inhibited. Hypertension and hypochromic anaemia may be seen.

Cadmium is said to be carcinogenic, and increased incidence of lung, prostrate, pancreas and bladder carcinoma has been reported.

Option A: OP compounds are anti-cholinesterase agents(ChE inhibitors)

Option B: The muscarinic manifestations may lead to bradycardia or tachycardia; but predominantly bradycardia.

Option D: Nicotinic manifestations on striated muscle leads to initial stimulus results in contraction. Later there is paralysis due to persistent depolarisation.

  • Chemical tests to detect urine from the stains depend on the presence of Urea and creatinine.

questions.text: A criminal act done under impulse is not punishable under
questions.solution:
Irresistible impulse test (New Hampshire doctrine): An accused is not criminally responsible, even if knows the nature and quality of his act and knows that it is wrong, if he is incapable of restraining himself from committing the act, because the free agency of his will has been destroyed by mental disease.

American law institute (ALI) test: A person is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, as a result of mental disease or defect lacked substantial capacity either to appreciate the wrongfulness of his conduct or to conform his conduct to the requirements of the law.

Durham's rule: An accused is not criminally responsible if his unlawful act is the product of mental Disease or mental Defect.

Currens rule: An accused is not criminally responsible, if at the time of committing the act, the defendant, as a result of mental disease or defect, lacks substantial Capacity to Conform his Conduct to the requirements of law.

Reference: The Yale Law Journal Company, Inc.

questions.text: How many sputum samples are needed for the diagnosis of TB?
questions.solution:
b. 2 sputum samples:This option aligns with the standard practice recommended by RNTCP. Collecting two sputum samples allows for increased sensitivity in detecting Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the causative agent of TB, and is considered adequate for initial diagnosis.

Explanation to why other options are not correct:

a. 1 sputum sample: While it's possible to detect tuberculosis with just one sputum sample, the Revised National Tuberculosis Control Program (RNTCP) in India typically recommends collecting two sputum samples for initial diagnosis. This is because having multiple samples increases the likelihood of detecting the bacteria responsible for TB, especially considering the intermittent shedding of the bacteria in sputum.

c. 3 sputum samples: While collecting three sputum samples may increase the chances of detecting TB bacteria, it's not typically necessary for initial diagnosis under RNTCP guidelines. Usually, if the first two samples are negative, additional diagnostic tests may be considered rather than collecting a third sample.

d. 4 sputum samples: Collecting four sputum samples is not standard practice for diagnosing TB under RNTCP guidelines. It would be excessive and impractical in most cases. The program aims for a balance between diagnostic sensitivity and practicality in resource-limited settings.

In summary, while it's possible to diagnose TB with just one sputum sample, the standard practice recommended by RNTCP is to collect two sputum samples for initial diagnosis. This option provides a balance between diagnostic accuracy and practicality in resource-limited settings, making it the most appropriate choice.

questions.text: Census method used in India
questions.solution:
The census method used in India is primarily based on the De Jure system.

De Jure System:

  • In the De Jure system, individuals are counted based on their legal status or residency at a particular location, irrespective of whether they are physically present there during the census period.
  • This method is suitable for countries like India, where large populations are mobile, and people might be absent from their usual place of residence during the census period due to various reasons such as work, travel, or temporary relocation.
  • India's census enumerators visit households and record information about individuals based on their legal residence, including those who may be away at the time of the census.
  • The De Jure system ensures a comprehensive count of the population, including individuals who are temporarily absent but legally residents of a particular area.

Reason for Choosing De Jure System in India:

  • India has a vast and diverse population with significant internal migration patterns. Many people move within the country for employment, education, or other reasons.
  • Implementing a De Jure system allows the census to capture the entire population, including those who might be away from their usual place of residence during the census period.
  • It ensures that individuals are not excluded from the census count merely because they are temporarily absent, thus providing a more accurate representation of the population.

a. Why Not De Facto System:

  • In a De Facto system, individuals are counted based on their physical presence at the time of the census.
  • This method may not be suitable for countries like India due to its high levels of internal migration. It could result in undercounting certain segments of the population, particularly migrant workers or students who might be away from their usual place of residence during the census period.
  • Exclusively using a De Facto system could lead to inaccuracies in the census data and hinder effective planning and resource allocation.

b. Why Not Both:

  • While some countries may employ a combination of De Jure and De Facto methods, India primarily relies on the De Jure system due to its specific demographic and geographic characteristics.
  • Implementing both methods simultaneously might introduce complexity and potential inconsistencies in the census data, making it challenging to ensure accuracy and reliability.

c. Why Not None:

  • Not employing any census method would result in a lack of official population data, which is essential for government planning, policy formulation, resource allocation, and various socio-economic activities.
  • Conducting a census using a recognised method is crucial for maintaining accurate demographic records and facilitating evidence-based decision-making at both national and local levels.

In conclusion, India predominantly uses the De Jure system for its census method due to the country's demographic complexity, high levels of internal migration, and the need to ensure a comprehensive count of the population. This method helps capture the entire population, including those temporarily absent, thereby providing a more accurate representation of India's diverse populace.
